provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799-1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; by inheritance in 1862 to Captain F. J. Butts; by inheritance in 1905 to his widow; sold April 1906 through Carfax & Co. to W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 3 (£997.10s. to Mrs. A. B. Clifton); sold by Clifton in 1961 through Thomas Agnew & Sons to Paul Mellon; given by Mellon in 1977 to the Yale Center for British Art.

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower right with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The signature is damaged and very difficult to see. An enhanced image of the monogram has been provided below.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates the scene of Abraham preparing to sacrifice his son, Isaac (Genesis 22:9), but the action portrayed also includes the binding and release of Isaac, since a ram caught in the bushes is visible to the left of the central figures (Genesis 22:13). The figures of Abraham and Isaac dominate the design. Abraham is portrayed as an old man with long hair and a beard. He wears a gown and faces forward, but looks up slightly. In his left hand, he holds a dagger. Isaac, nude with short, curly hair, is seen from behind. He stands in front of and slightly to the left of his father, looking up at him. His right leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. With his left arm, raised horizontally though bent slightly, he points to a ram caught in the bushes. The ram, to the left of Abraham and Issac, lies with its curled horns tangled in some leafless branches. It lies on a rock, with its head down. Surrounding the ram are a number of trees, with both leafless and leafy branches, as well as indeterminate vegetation. To the right of Abraham and Isaac is a stone altar, with a bundle of sticks and a footed bowl or goblet on top. The sky is at once cloudy and fiery, perhaps indicating a sunset or sunrise, or a divine presence. There may be grass in the foreground below the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: The figures of Abraham and his son Isaac dominate the design. Abraham is portrayed as an old man with long hair and a beard. He wears a gown and faces forward, but looks up and to the right slightly. His arms are raised at 45 degrees. In his left hand, he holds a dagger; he may be pointing to or touching the ram with his right hand. His expression suggests regret or melancholy sadness.

The figures of Abraham and Isaac dominate the design. Isaac, nude with short, curly hair, is seen from behind. He stands in front of and slightly to the left of his father, looking up at him. His right leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. With his left arm, raised horizontally though bent slightly, he points to or touches a ram caught in the bushes.
The ram, to the left of Abraham and Issac, lies with its curled horns tangled in some leafless branches. It lies on a rock, with its head down.
Surrounding the ram are a number of trees, with both leafless and leafy branches, as well as indeterminate vegetation. Roots on the two trees lower left in the foreground may be visible.
There may be grass in the foreground along the lower margin of the design.
To the right of Abraham and Isaac is a stone altar, with a bundle of sticks and a footed bowl or goblet on top.
The sky is at once cloudy and fiery, perhaps indicating a sunset or sunrise, or a divine presence. There may be hills or distant mountains on the horizon, particularly on the left.
